educational_objective: Treat stage 2 hypertension with combination therapy.
question_text: A 54-year-old man is evaluated during a follow-up visit for elevated blood pressure. One month ago, he had an office blood pressure measurement of 160/94 mm Hg. Subsequently, 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring revealed an average blood pressure of 152/92 mm Hg. He is asymptomatic. He smokes 10 cigarettes daily. There is no family history of hypertension. He takes no medications.On physical examination, blood pressure is 158/94 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 78/min. Other vital signs and the remainder of the examination are normal.Serum creatinine, electrolyte, glucose, and thyroid-stimulating hormone levels are normal. Urinalysis findings are normal.A 12-lead ECG is normal.His 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk is 16%, and rosuvastatin is initiated.
question_stem: In addition to lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
critique: The most appropriate additional treatment for this patient with stage 2 hypertension is amlodipine-benazepril (Option A). The 2017 American College of Cardiology (ACC)/American Heart Association (AHA) blood pressure (BP) guideline recommends combination therapy with two first-line antihypertensive drugs of different classes for adults with stage 2 hypertension and an average BP of 20/10 mm Hg above their BP target; this typically correlates with a BP ≥150/90 mm Hg. There are no definitive recommendations for best drug combinations; however, some data suggest that an ACE inhibitor/calcium channel blocker (CCB) combination may be more effective than an ACE inhibitor/thiazide diuretic combination. A thiazide diuretic/CCB combination may also be an option. The 2017 ACC/AHA BP guideline recommends a BP target of <130/80 mm Hg for patients who have established cardiovascular disease or for patients with an estimated atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) event risk ≥10%. This patient has stage 2 hypertension (office-based readings ≥140/90 mm Hg) and an ASCVD event risk of ≥10%, and his average BP is >20/10 mm Hg above his target of <130/80 mm Hg. Therefore, combination antihypertensive therapy is warranted.Starting chlorthalidone (Option B) or nifedipine (Option D) as monotherapy would each be appropriate as first-line therapy for patients with stage 1 hypertension (systolic BP of 130-139 mm Hg or diastolic BP of 80-89 mm Hg). However, monotherapy is unlikely to effectively control this patient's BP because he has stage 2 hypertension with an average BP that is 20/10 mm Hg above his BP target.Metoprolol-hydrochlorothiazide (Option C) is not the most appropriate first choice of combination therapy for this patient. Metoprolol and other β-blockers are not considered first-line therapy in the treatment of hypertension unless a compelling indication, such as a recent myocardial infarction or heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, is also present. Although there are no definitive recommendations for antihypertensive combination drug regimens in patients with stage 2 hypertension, the two drugs chosen should be from the three first-line classes of antihypertensive drugs, namely ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers, calcium channel blockers, and thiazide diuretics.
key_points: The 2017 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association blood pressure (BP) guideline recommends combination therapy with two first-line antihypertensive drugs of different classes for adults with stage 2 hypertension and an average BP of 20/10 mm Hg above their BP target (typically ≥150/90 mm Hg).
